message.publisher: American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS)

funder.name: Japan Society for the Promotion of Science

message.abstract:
<jats:title>Plant thirst quenched without water</jats:title>
          <jats:p>
            Drought causes many billions of dollars of annual losses to farmers worldwide. Central to a plant's water use efficiency are signaling pathways regulated by the hormone abscisic acid and its receptors. Vaidya
            <jats:italic>et al.</jats:italic>
            screened a pool of candidate small molecules and used structure-guided design to optimize the function of an abscisic acid receptor agonist (see the Perspective by Phillips and Sussman). Application of the agonist protected
            <jats:italic>Arabidopsis</jats:italic>
            , wheat, and tomato from underwatering.
          </jats:p>
          <jats:p>
            <jats:italic>Science</jats:italic>
            , this issue p.
            <jats:related-article xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" ext-link-type="doi" related-article-type="in-this-issue" xlink:href="10.1126/science.aaw8848">eaaw8848</jats:related-article>
            ; see also p.
            <jats:related-article xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" ext-link-type="doi" issue="6464" page="416" related-article-type="in-this-issue" vol="366" xlink:href="10.1126/science.aaz4857">416</jats:related-article>
          </jats:p>
title: Dynamic control of plant water use using designed ABA receptor agonists
